metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: ML Terminology
Machine Learning Relationships
Machine learning systems uses Relationships between Inputs to produce Predictions .
content.html: Machine learning systems uses Relationships between Inputs to produce Predictions.

content.text: In algebra, a relationship is often written as y = ax + b :
content.html: In algebra, a relationship is often written as y = ax + b:

content.text: With ML, a relationship is written as y = b + wx :
content.html: With ML, a relationship is written as y = b + wx:

content.text: Machine Learning Labels
In Machine Learning terminology, the label is the thing we want to predict .
content.html: In Machine Learning terminology, the label is the thing we want to predict.

content.text: It is like the y in a linear graph:
content.html: It is like the y in a linear graph:

content.text: Machine Learning Features
In Machine Learning terminology, the features are the input .
content.html: In Machine Learning terminology, the features are the input.

content.text: They are like the x values in a linear graph:
content.html: They are like the x values in a linear graph:

content.text: Sometimes there can be many features (input values) with different weights:
content.html: Sometimes there can be many features (input values) with different weights:

content.text: y = b + w 1 x 1 + w 2 x 2 + w 3 x 3 + w 4 x 4
content.html: y = b + w1x1 + w2x2 + w3x3 + w4x4

content.text: Machine Learning Models
A Model defines the relationship between the label (y) and the features (x).
content.html: A Model defines the relationship between the label (y) and the features (x).

content.text: There are three phases in the life of a model:
content.html: There are three phases in the life of a model:

content.text: Machine Learning Training
The goal of training is to create a model that can answer a question. Like what is the expected price for a house?
content.html: The goal of training is to create a model that can answer a question. Like what is the expected price for a house?

content.text: Machine Learning Inference
Inference is when the trained model is used to infer (predict) values using live data. Like putting the model into production.
content.html: Inference is when the trained model is used to infer (predict) values using live data. Like putting the model into production.

content.text: Machine Learning Phases
Machine learning has two main phases:
content.html: Machine learning has two main phases:

content.text: 1. Training : Input data are used to calculate the parameters of the model.
content.html:
1. Training:
Input data are used to calculate the parameters of the model.

content.text: 2. Inference : The "trained" model outputs correct data from any input.
content.html:
2. Inference:
The "trained" model outputs correct data from any input.

content.text: Supervised Learning
Supervised Machine Learning uses a set of input variables to predict the value of an output variable.
content.html: Supervised Machine Learning uses a set of input variables to predict the value of an output variable.

content.text: Supervised learning uses labeled data (data with known answers) to train algorithms to:
content.html: Supervised learning uses labeled data (data with known answers) to train algorithms to:

content.text: Supervised learning can classify data like "What is spam in an e-mail", based on known spam examples.
content.html: Supervised learning can classify data like "What is spam in an e-mail", based on known spam examples.

content.text: Supervised learning can predict outcomes like predicting what kind of video you like, based on the videos you have played.
content.html: Supervised learning can predict outcomes like predicting what kind of video you like, based on the videos you have played.

content.text: Unsupervised Learning
Unsupervised Machine Learning uses patterns from any unlabeled dataset, trying to understand patterns (or groupings) in the data.
content.html: Unsupervised Machine Learning uses patterns from any unlabeled dataset, trying to understand patterns (or groupings) in the data.

content.text: Unsupervised learning is used to predict undefined relationships like meaningful patterns in data.
content.html: Unsupervised learning is used to predict undefined relationships like meaningful patterns in data.

content.text: It is about creating computer algorithms than can improve themselves.
content.html: It is about creating computer algorithms than can improve themselves.

content.text: It is expected that machine learning will shift to unsupervised learning to allow programmers to solve problems without creating models.
content.html: It is expected that machine learning will shift to unsupervised learning to allow programmers to solve problems without creating models.

content.text: Reinforcement Learning
Reinforcement learning is based on non-supervised learning but receives feedback from the user whether the decision is good or bad. The feedback contributes to improving the model.
content.html: Reinforcement learning is based on non-supervised learning but receives feedback from the user whether the decision is good or bad. The feedback contributes to improving the model.

content.text: Self-Supervised Learning
Self-supervised learning is similar to unsupervised learning because it works with data without human added labels.
content.html: Self-supervised learning is similar to unsupervised learning because it works with data without human added labels.

content.text: The difference is that unsupervised learning uses clustering, grouping, and dimensionality reduction, while self-supervised learning draw its own conclusions for regression and classification tasks.
content.html: The difference is that unsupervised learning uses clustering, grouping, and dimensionality reduction, while self-supervised learning draw its own conclusions for regression and classification tasks.
